Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2014 07:31PM bonnets wrote: JenJen, Hope so too. I have been having pain off and on for 3 or 4 months. If I reach wrong, turn wrong, have a difficult BM, I can have awful pain in my ribs on the lumpectomy side. I tend to worry cuz I had a daughter who passed at 33 from BC. Also my surgery was on the lower inner quadrant, closer to the ribs. Been 2 years since I finished rads. I have been reading of others who are experiencing various pains on that side, for years, but I did want to make sure! Pray you have a good result too. Hate waiting!

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2014 03:03AM bonnets wrote: Ho ladies, new here have been on the "older  women's " board off and on for 2 years. I'm an ole lady of 72 this month! I have been having  rib pain on  my lumpectomy side for several months. My MO did a rib series X-ray, which was neg, 2 months ago. Still having pain when I reach, strain and to the touch. Went to my Rads onc yesterday to see if he thought it was from rads, I finished them 2 years ago. I know it is a possible SE  of rads.  He thinks maybe inflammation, put me on  Ibuprofin for 10 days. He also did a repeat  rib series, won't know the results til Wed. I know X-rays don't always show bone mets , so even if it is neg I'm going to request a bone scan or MRI!  I am BRCA neg, though my daughter passed at 32  from BC diagnosed at 27. No other family history No one seem s to be worried but me, can't help but think this is bone mets. Thanks, Jean

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2012 05:28PM - edited Sep 19, 2012 05:31PM by bonnets When my daughter had drains  we found Fanny packs , worn in fromt helped with the drains. I had the  breast incision, about 2+ inches on the innet aspect of my boob, and the axillary, which is the most uncomfortable, tried several stretchy soft bras, one works good for night, one for day, as Im told to wear a bra 24/7. I don't have any drains! Jean P.S. maybe a small hole in the bra, run the drainage tube thru and insert in the bottle, which you carry in a fanny pack?!

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 08:37PM bonnets wrote: Benny,  Tried to post  2 times and the message didn't go thru. I'll try again. I agree with the other ladies , that you need to call and try and get in to see your surgeon early. If nothing else to  feel more at peace. I have a seroma, started out as a lump about the size of an egg. Have a friend who had one the size of an orange. She had hers drained for several days. MIne has shrunk some in the last few days. I cud actually sleep on that side  for a while last night. O also noticed you dont sleep in your bra. My dr. told me wear one 24/7. Don't like that but am doing it, s it offers the breast support. You may feel better if you try that. Hope things feel better, hugs, Jean
